Tribute Page

Waldo

The Costa Rican Two-Toed Sloth

The story of how I met Waldo on the side of the road in Costa Rica...

I first met Waldo on a small side road in a small town called Limon on the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica. He was trying to scamper up a tree as fast as his two toes would take him and I was trying to get out camera in time to take a photograph of him. Here I was like a paparazzi trying to catch the star before they escaped. Waldo was so close I could have reached out and touched him but something kept me from doing so, perhaps it was the green fuzz that appeared to be growing on him or just the look in his eyes asking to be left alone, and so I stuck to photography.

Waldo was the first sloth I would see on that trip but he would not be the last.

Pictured: A sloth that looks like Waldo - The Two Toed Sloth

Here is a bit of info about these loveable little critters...
A.k.a. Sloth Facts

  • Two-Toed Sloths are usually bigger than their three toed sloth cousins.
  • Two toed sloths actually have two fingers in their hands and three in their toes.
  • Sloths cannot shiver to keep warm when they get cold. Good thing they live in warm areas.
  • Two toed sloths descend down vines and trees head first in contrast to three toed sloths which descend rump first.
  • Sloths are fantastic swimmers.
  • Sloths only use the bathroom for number two once a week.
Additional Information on Two Toed Sloths can be found on Wikipedia.com

Sloth Habitat

Two toed sloths can be found through the tropical rainforests of Central and South America. They are usually found among the forest canopy and prefer a habitat that is lush with vegetation so they have an abundance of twigs and plant life to dine on. Sloths often prefer an environment next to water because despite their slow movement in the forest canopy they are excellent swimmers and enjoy an occasional dip in rivers or oceans.

The Giant Ground Sloth

Imagine a sloth the size of an elephant. It would be far too large to swing through the trees so instead it would have crawled through the jungle floor and utilize its gigantic claws for digging through the dirt and forging for food. That would have been the Giant Ground sloth. These colossal sloths existed over 35 million years ago and are believed to have migrated up from the southern tip of South America all the way to the Appalachian areas of North America. Footprints found in New Mexico show that prehistoric humans hunted the giant sloth during the ice age. Sadly, these magnificent behemoths went extinct around 11,000 years ago.
